analysis.raw_analysis:
1) TRANSFORMATION TYPE: Output keeps same dimensions as input (1:1); pattern fills full rows or columns (no scaling).

2) PATTERN: Find the two single colored seed cells; choose orientation by grid shape (if height>width -> horizontal bands, else vertical); take their axis coordinates, compute spacing = their coordinate difference, start at the smaller coordinate and paint full orthogonal lines of thickness1 every spacing, alternating the two seed colors downward/rightward.

3) KEY CHANGES:
- Ex1: start row5 color2 then row7 color3, repeat every 2 rows alternating (fills full rows).
- Ex2: start col5 color1 then col8 color3, repeat every 3 cols alternating (fills full cols).
- Ex3: start row7 color4 then row11 color1, repeat every 4 rows alternating (fills full rows).
- Ex4: start col5 color2 then col7 color8, repeat every 2 cols alternating (fills full cols).

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
Each input has exactly two single-pixel seeds of different colors (ex1: 2 & 3; ex2: 1 & 3; ex3: 4 & 1; ex4: 2 & 8). Grid aspect (height>width or width>height) differs and determines orientation. Seed coordinates lie on the axis (row or column) that will be expanded.

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
All outputs keep input dimensions. They produce full-row or full-column stripes only, alternating the two seed colors, with a black (0) stripe between colored stripes. The stripe that contains a seed uses that seed's color.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
Rule: detect the two single-pixel seed colors c1,c2 and their positions. If height>width, paint full horizontal stripes at every 2nd row starting at each seed's row, alternating c1 and c2 downward; if width>=height, do the same with vertical stripes at every 2nd column starting at each seed's column. Background remains 0.

Reference objects: The two single-pixel seeds (positions + colors) are preserved and drive the transform.

Grid pattern: Fill full rows or full columns with the two seed colors, alternating. Orientation = the axis with the smaller non-zero separation (if columns equal -> horizontal). Period = the distance between the seeds along that axis; start at the smaller coordinate and repeat across the grid.

Objects: The two seeds are the only important objects; their colors, order and spacing define stripe color, order and spacing. Background remains black.

=== GENERAL RULE ===
Step 1: IF the input grid contains exactly two cells whose value is not 0 and those two cells have different color values (call them seed A at (rA,cA) with color colorA and seed B at (rB,cB) with color colorB) THEN identify and record (rA,cA,colorA) and (rB,cB,colorB) as the two single-pixel seeds to drive the pattern.

Step 2: IF the grid height (number of rows) is greater than the grid width (number of columns) THEN set orientation = horizontal (meaning you will paint full rows).

Step 3: IF the grid width (number of columns) is greater than the grid height (number of rows) THEN set orientation = vertical (meaning you will paint full columns).

Step 4: IF the grid width equals the grid height THEN set orientation = horizontal.

Step 5: IF orientation = horizontal THEN compute period = |rA - rB|; IF period = 0 THEN set period = 1; set start = min(rA,rB); THEN for every integer k such that row = start + k * period lies within the grid, fill every cell in that full row with color = colorA when k is even and color = colorB when k is odd; leave all other cells (not on those rows) at color 0.

Step 6: IF orientation = vertical THEN compute period = |cA - cB|; IF period = 0 THEN set period = 1; set start = min(cA,cB); THEN for every integer k such that column = start + k * period lies within the grid, fill every cell in that full column with color = colorA when k is even and color = colorB when k is odd; leave all other cells (not on those columns) at color 0.

Step 7: IF any of the original two seed cells exist in the grid THEN they remain their original color (this is ensured because the filled rows/columns use the seed colors and preserve the seeds' colors).

Step 7: IF any of the original two seed cells exist in the grid THEN they remain their original color (this is ensured because the filled rows/columns use the seed colors and preserve the seeds' colors).

general_steps.instruction: Step 1: OBSERVE - IF the input grid contains exactly two cells whose value is not 0 and those two cells have different color values (call them seed A at (rA,cA) with color colorA and seed B at (rB,cB) with color colorB) THEN identify and record (rA,cA,colorA) and (rB,cB,colorB) as the two single-pixel seeds to drive the pattern.

general_steps.instruction: Step 2: TRANSFORM - IF the grid height (number of rows) is greater than the grid width (number of columns) THEN set orientation = horizontal (meaning you will paint full rows).
general_steps.condition: the grid height (number of rows) is greater than the grid width (number of columns)

general_steps.instruction: Step 3: TRANSFORM - IF the grid width (number of columns) is greater than the grid height (number of rows) THEN set orientation = vertical (meaning you will paint full columns).

general_steps.instruction: Step 5: TRANSFORM - IF orientation = horizontal THEN compute period = |rA - rB|; IF period = 0 THEN set period = 1; set start = min(rA,rB); THEN for every integer k such that row = start + k * period lies within the grid, fill every cell in that full row with color = colorA when k is even and color = colorB when k is odd; leave all other cells (not on those rows) at color 0.

Step 6: TRANSFORM - IF orientation = vertical THEN compute period = |cA - cB|; IF period = 0 THEN set period = 1; set start = min(cA,cB); THEN for every integer k such that column = start + k * period lies within the grid, fill every cell in that full column with color = colorA when k is even and color = colorB when k is odd; leave all other cells (not on those columns) at color 0.

Step 7: TRANSFORM - IF any of the original two seed cells exist in the grid THEN they remain their original color (this is ensured because the filled rows/columns use the seed colors and preserve the seeds' colors).
